title: Omicron Is Fast Moving, but Perhaps Less Severe, Early Reports Suggest
content: Researchers in South Africa, where the variant is spreading quickly, say it may cause less serious Covid cases than other forms of the virus, but it is unclear whether that will hold true.

more_info.byline: By Lynsey Chutel, Richard Pérez-Peña and Emily Anthes

title: New York City to Mandate Vaccines for Employees at Private Businesses
content: The mandate, set to take effect just before Mayor Bill de Blasio leaves office, will apply to workers at about 184,000 businesses. It is likely to face legal challenges.

title: Will Eric Adams Keep N.Y.C.’s Newest Vaccine Mandate? Check Back Later.
content: It was unclear if the incoming mayor, Eric Adams, who is on vacation in Ghana, intended to enforce a vaccine mandate for private employers.

title: Stricter coronavirus testing rules take effect for travelers flying to the U.S.
content: Inbound travelers must now show a negative result from a test taken no more than a day before departure, a requirement some say may be hard to satisfy.

more_info.byline: By Juston Jones and Jenny Gross

title: Spike in Omicron Variant Cases Puts Europe on Edge
content: With cases of the Omicron variant rising in Europe, there are worries that even tougher restrictions are looming over a holiday period that many had hoped would be a return to some normalcy.

more_info.byline: By Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai

title: Biden Expected to Offer Warnings and Alternatives in Call With Putin
content: The conflict in Ukraine will be a major topic during a high-stakes video call between President Biden and Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday.

more_info.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: On Ukrainian Front, Grinding War and Weary Anticipation of Invasion
content: After eight years in the trenches, Ukrainian soldiers are resigned to the possibility that the Russian military, which dwarfs their own in power and wealth, will come sooner or later.

title: Justice Dept. Files Voting Rights Suit Against Texas Over New Map
content: The department said the state’s redistricting plan would violate the Voting Rights Act by discriminating against minority voters.

more_info.byline: By Katie Benner, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

title: U.S. Will Not Send Government Officials to Beijing Olympics
content: American athletes will still be able to compete in the Winter Games, but the diplomatic boycott is a slap at China for human rights abuses in Xinjiang.

des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

title: Right vs. Right vs. Left: Governor’s Race Puts Georgia at Center of 2022 Drama
content: Former Senator David Perdue, encouraged by Donald Trump, is challenging Gov. Brian Kemp, a fellow Republican who defied the former president.

more_info.byline: By Richard Fausset and Jonathan Martin

title: Trump’s Media Company Is Investigated Over Financing Deal
content: A financing company told investors that it wasn’t in deal talks, weeks after its C.E.O. held a private videoconference about a possible deal with Donald Trump.

more_info.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, David Enrich and Michael Schwirtz

title: Devin Nunes Will Quit the House to Take Over Trump’s Media Company
content: The California Republican, who had pugnaciously defended Donald J. Trump, chose the media company role over a potentially powerful new post in Congress.

title: Justice Department Closes Emmett Till Investigation Without Charges
content: The department said it could not corroborate a book’s claim that a central witness had recanted her statements about Emmett, a Black teenager killed by two white men in 1955.

more_info.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and Tariro Mzezewa

title: Alana Haim Surprised Everyone With Her Movie Debut. Even Herself.
content: When Paul Thomas Anderson asked her to star in “Licorice Pizza,” the musician had zero acting experience. Now she’s winning rave reviews.

title: Why New York Is Unearthing a Brook It Buried a Century Ago
content: A plan to “daylight” Tibbetts Brook in the Bronx would be one of the city’s most ambitious green infrastructure improvements.

more_info.byline: By Winnie Hu and James Thomas

title: What Comes Next for an Artist Whose Work Goes Viral?
content: With the animated video series “2 Lizards,” Meriem Bennani and Orian Barki captured the essence of 2020. Now, Bennani’s at work on a documentary about living in limbo.

title: Chanel, TikTok and the Beauty Advent Calendar Controversy
content: Some social media users are not feeling the Christmas spirit — or this box of mini lipsticks and branded stickers.

title: Best Movies of 2021
content: Even when a film wasn’t great, filmgoing was. But there were some truly wonderful releases, ranging from music docs and musicals to westerns and the just plain weird.

title: Opioids Feel Like Love. That’s Why They’re Deadly in Tough Times.
content: America can’t arrest its way out of a problem caused by the fundamental human need to connect.

title: I Tried to Change Bob Dole. Now I Realize He Was Right.
content: During his 1996 presidential campaign, Senator Dole would often go off script. But it was those moments that revealed his rare empathy.

title: He Is Black. The Victims Were White. ‘It’s an Allegation as Old as America.’
content: The halting of executions and the guilty verdicts in the Ahmaud Arbery case have given us the slightest bit of hope for change.

title: Can We Help the Homeless?
content: Why it’s so difficult to find viable solutions for California’s homelessness crisis.

title: We Are Not Going to Run Out of Hypocrisy Anytime Soon
content: Yet another school shooting, the Supreme Court argument over Roe and much else in American life give us pause.

title: Why Humans Aren’t the Worst (Despite, Well, Everything Happening in the World)
content: The historian Rutger Bregman makes a case for the “collective brilliance” of humanity.

title: Biden’s Democracy Conference Is About Much More Than Democracy
content: Democracies can find strength in numbers.

title: How Can You Destroy a Person’s Life and Only Get a Slap on the Wrist?
content: The Justice Department’s Office of Professional Responsibility needs an overhaul.

title: The Ghosts of Mississippi
content: Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization is another Mississippi case poised to roll back constitutional rights.

title: Rudeness Is On the Rise. You Got a Problem With That?
content: How do we respond to a culture in which the guardrails of so-called civility are gone?

title: Is My Little Library Contributing to the Gentrification of My Black Neighborhood?
content: Thoughts I had as I watched a white couple browsing books.

content: Giving thanks for everything from stents to foliage to a musical dog.

title: Heeding Warning Signs Before School Shootings
content: Readers criticize the school’s decision to allow Ethan Crumbley back into class, and the nation’s gun laws. Also: Chris Cuomo; gender-neutral in French; happiness.

title: Josh Hawley and the Republican Obsession With Manliness
content: The Missouri senator is tapping into something real — a widespread, politically potent anxiety about young men that is already helping the right.

title: The Abortion I Didn’t Have
content: I never thought about ending my pregnancy. Instead, at 19, I erased the future I had imagined for myself.

title: Condé Nast Knows Its Faded Glory Is Not in Style
content: Anna Wintour is the embodiment of the glory days of the magazine dynasty. Now she is pitching its global, digital future.

title: After Success in Seating Federal Judges, Biden Hits Resistance
content: Senate Democrats vow to keep pressing forward with nominees, but they may face obstacles in states represented by Republicans.

title: Facing Economic Collapse, Afghanistan Is Gripped by Starvation
content: An estimated 22.8 million people — more than half the country’s population — are expected to face potentially life-threatening food insecurity this winter. Many are already on the brink of catastrophe.

title: Christmas Tree Questions? Ask the Mayor of Rockefeller Center.
content: For two decades, Correll Jones has been the man to ask about New York’s most famous tree — and where to find the public bathrooms.

title: New York City, Redistricting, Ukraine: Your Monday Evening Briefing
content: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Could Breaking Up Meta Make Things Worse?
content: The parent company of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp reaches 3.6 billion active users. But is its size actually against the public’s interest?

content: After the death of Jeffrey Epstein, what kind of justice is possible without him?

title: How Is the Pandemic Reshaping New York City’s Cultural Landscape?
content: Join playwright Lynn Nottage, artist Laurie Anderson and writer Sarah Schulman in a virtual event on Dec. 9 to explore the current recovery through the lens of previous eras of cultural resurrection.

title: Inside Tesla as Elon Musk Pushed an Unflinching Vision for Self-Driving Cars
content: The automaker may have undermined safety in designing its Autopilot driver-assistance system to fit its chief executive’s vision, former employees say.

title: A Meeting With Maxwell Led to Years of Sex With Epstein, Accuser Says
content: A woman identified only as “Kate” told jurors at Ghislaine Maxwell’s sex-trafficking trial that Ms. Maxwell leveraged their friendship to encourage her to have sex with Jeffrey Epstein.

more_info.byline: By Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Benjamin Weiser

title: Trump’s Blood Oxygen Level in Covid Bout Was Dangerously Low, Former Aide Says
content: Mark Meadows, Mr. Trump’s former chief of staff, said in his new book that the weakened president’s blood oxygen level reached 86 during a harrowing fight against the coronavirus.

more_info.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Noah Weiland
org_facet: Reed, Walter, National Military Medical Center

title: Defendant in Case Brought by Durham Says New Evidence Undercuts Charge
content: Lawyers for Michael Sussmann, accused by the Trump-era special counsel of lying to the F.B.I., asked for a quick trial after receiving what they said was helpful material from prosecutors.

des_facet: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

title: Biden’s Supreme Court Commission Prepares to Vote on Final Report
content: A draft version of the document flagged deep disputes over court expansion while exploring how phasing in term limits might work.

title: Medina Spirit, an Embattled Kentucky Derby Winner, Dies During a Workout
content: The colt suffered an apparent heart attack while working out at the Santa Anita Park racetrack. California racing officials pledged to do a necropsy and make their findings public.

title: Fred Hiatt, Washington Post Editorial Page Editor, Dies at 66
content: He used his powerful platform to champion human rights, caution against a Trump presidency and condemn the killing of a Saudi columnist for the paper.

title: Man Charged With Sending Dozens of Violent Threats to L.G.B.T.Q. Groups
content: Robert Fehring warned that an attack on New York City’s Pride March would make the Pulse nightclub shooting “look like a cakewalk,” the authorities said.

title: Touting His Spending Bill, Biden Shifts Focus to Drug Prices
content: President Biden emphasized how the bill would lower prescription drug costs, an issue his administration hopes will build support for the broader package.

more_info.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Margot Sanger-Katz

title: Drake Removes Himself From Competition for 2022 Grammy Awards
content: The superstar rapper and singer, long a critic of the awards, was nominated in two categories, best rap album and best rap performance.

more_info.byline: By Ben Sisario and Joe Coscarelli

title: Are My Stomach Problems Really All in My Head?
content: Scientists often debate whether irritable bowel syndrome is a mental or physical issue. That’s not much help for those who suffer from it.

title: A Perplexing Marijuana Side Effect Relieved by Hot Showers
content: Emergency room doctors are seeing a growing caseload of nausea and vomiting in marijuana users whose only relief is a long, hot shower.

title: What Is Sensory Processing Disorder?
content: Children who are deemed ‘sensitive’ or ‘picky’ might be struggling with a treatable condition.

title: The Temporary Memory Lapse of Transient Global Amnesia
content: Those with T.G.A. do not experience any alteration in consciousness or abnormal movements. Only the ability to lay down memories is affected.

title: When the Neurologist Really Knows How Patients Feel
content: I can’t undo the damage of a stroke I had as an infant, but I can try to help other patients face similar diagnoses.

content: In the ’90s, “Sex and the City” celebrated single women. Can a new, more nuanced version make a comedy of middle-aged ones?

content: The HBO mini-series stars Olivia Colman and David Thewlis as a British couple convicted of killing the wife’s parents and burying them in the backyard.

title: No Matter the Role, Antony Sher Made Soaring Seem Possible
content: The actor, who died at the age of 72, was known for his commanding performances of Shakespeare’s Richard III and the Auschwitz survivor Primo Levi.

title: The Timesian Urge to Explain a Meme
content: Journalists love subjecting online jokes to semantic dissection. So, shall we?

title: He Was a Black Star 60 Years Before Jackie. Now He’s a Hall of Famer.
content: Elected by the Hall’s Early Days committee, Bud Fowler was a pioneer who played organized professional baseball against white players as early as 1878.
